Posts.Title: One Month Later - Mastectomy photos if anyone would like to see

Posts.Content: Hi Emma Sorry I didn't come back to you on the pain issue, i went to my dad's for the weekend.  There was no pain really at all.  my whole chest area felt very numb as i guess they give you a whole host of painkillers during the operation.    I was up and about and left hospital the day after op (and the op had been late in the day).  the drains are a bit of a nuisance but again nothing to worry about.   i only took paracetomol and really hardly at all.   maybe for the first day or so.   i did have a weird phantom nipple feeling which was odd but that has gone.   I have most of the feeling back now in my chest, it seems to get better by the day, i had a tight chord feeling from my bottom rib to my armpit but that has gone too (have done lots of stretching and moving around).  I went through a few days of having a horrible burning sensation on my chest but now i am thinking maybe i used the Bio Oil too soon as it does contain some perfume.  Really, don't worry about pain - i think on the whole the mastectomy is not usually painful and if you do have any pain, they are quick to sort it out. Dawn xx http://newdawncancercare.blogspot.co.uk/

Posts.Content: Hi Berry Sorry I didn't respond to your post sooner - I went away to my dad's place and had to collect some of mum's things, even though it has been nearly a year now since she died.   I did take a lot of stuff before but I had to collect the final things as he has now moved to a warden assisted place.   God it's so hard isn't it to lose your mum.    Good that you have Peggy, it makes all the difference to have someone to sail these rough seas with and try and find a laugh and something positive in it.  we use the expression "cancer is a gift" a lot - kind of as a joke but in a way it has given me things I didn't have - like knowing that I can cope when I thought I couldn't or wouldn't be able to.  Mum's cancer was so horrific (stomach/secondary liver - very advanced when diagnosed).  I always thought I would fall apart if my mum or dad died but you don't but it is a hard road to travel and it grows you up really fast. Walking by the sea sounds fabulous - much as i love living in Oxfordshire I miss the sea a lot.   I grew up in South Africa, always by the coast.  Have been here half my life now though and loving it.    Lived in Brighton for a bit and loved the sea. Am going to Bahamas hopefully in the next couple of weeks (my brother lives there) and am planning on doing some yoga whilst there - there is a yoga centre on the beach there.   Did you have reconstruction?    Wishing you all the best with the chemo. Posts.Content: Canton04,  Glad to hear things are going well.   i thought my seromas were quite round, they looked like mini breasts which was quite nice but now one has gone and i am a little concave but hey, nothing to really complain about.   My arm stayed tight till quite recently but now it really has eased off, i can sleep on both sides and on my belly which I definitely couldn't do until about a week ago.   There were two sites on the bottom of my ribs that hurt a bit (don't know why) which are now fine as well. i think they steri strips are supposed to stay in place until they fall off but i took mine off because i am convinced i am allergic to them.   but they were pretty much ready to come off anyway. really good that your hubby has agreed to go with you to the appointment, it's always better if Terri is with me although she can't always be as has to work.   Enjoy London!!!    I love London but couldn't live there anymore - too much of a country mouse these days!. Posts.Title: stopping smoking!

Posts.Content: the doctor at our local surgery thought it was nothing just "lumpy breasts" but said she would send me for mammogram just to be sure.   I went for mammogram and ultrasound, saw the surgeon again that day after he looked at the results which showed something and he said he was sure it was "benign, benign, benign"(whilst banging his fist on the desk) but sent me for core biopsy just to be sure.  I went away to France for a couple of weeks holiday.  On return I got a phone call to go back to  hospital.   "not such good news, it's cancer" says he.   he seemed genuinely surprised.  So it was a shock and I would have preferred him to not be so enthusiastic about his diagnosis in the beginning.  I didn't use him as my surgeon after that.  i guess my experience is not the norm thank God and am pleased to hear that everyone else had a better experience.  i ended up having a lumpectomy without clear margins followed by a bilateral mastectomy.   my new surgeon did say after the lumpectomy where they found more cancer that mammograms don't work very well on me nor ultrasounds as they found more cancer as well with the mastectomies.  if i had just had the lumpectomy and it had been successful i would have had to have MRIs in future.

Posts.Content: Hi C Everyone is different and I can only speak for myself.  I think today the way I feel, I could definitely do a train journey and I am one week post bilateral as you know.   But I wouldn't do it.  Infections can start at any time and seromas can worsen (I have two seromas which at the moment are quite small).   After my Lumpectomy in October I got an infection and I quickly went to the night surgery and got antibiotics and was glad I was at home.   Is it something super special?   Is it for Christmas?  You need to weigh it all up, if anything went wrong, could you get back quickly?    Definitely no luggage as the other poster said.   I want to go away in January, have decided probably a train journey to Paris but I will see how I feel closer to the time.  If I am not confident I would rather hire a cottage in UK.    Am I right in thinking you are in France?  Have you asked the breast care nurse? Dawn x
